newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's Peters says Coalition will be fiscally tight.
newsitem.headline: NZ's Peters says Coalition will be fiscally tight.

text.p: Treasurer Winston Peters said on Friday in one of his first major speeches since his appointment last month that the new New Zealand coalition government would be fiscally "tight".
"The previous government had a reputation for being tight... I can assure bureaucrats the Coalition Government will be even tighter," he said in a speech to the opening of a hospital in Tauranga.

"It is a fundamental Coalition principle that an economic climate to foster growth can only be achieved through low inflation and prudent and conservative management of the government's coffers," Peters said.
"Over time this will lead to further tax cuts and reduced public debt."
"I shrink from the word austere, but the Coalition Government will be a stern guardian of the taxpayers' dollar," Peters said.
Duplication of government services would end.
Peters' nationalist New Zealand First Party joined with the conservative National Party to form a centre-right government last month.
Peters said health, the economy and education were identified during the October election as people's biggest worries.
He said the words "public service" would be put back into the vocabulary of health managers and the health system.

There would be a boost to health spending of up to $378 million in the next financial year, which would be directed towards "areas in the public health system in dire need of more resources". But Peters said that, as Treasurer, he would rigorously scrutinise how extra taxpayers' money would be spent on public health.
"There has never been any mandate for wastage and profligacy." -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
